cleaned_text: is usually defined as a particle of [matter](/wiki/Matter) that is between 1 and 100 [nanometres](/wiki/Nanometre) (nm) in [diameter](/wiki/Diameter). [[1]](#cite_note-epaXXXXa-1) [[2]](#cite_note-iupac2012a-2) The term is sometimes used for larger particles, up to 500 nm,[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] or fibers and tubes that are less than 100 nm in only two directions. [[3]](#cite_note-iupac2012b-3) At the lowest range, metal particles smaller than 1 nm are usually called [atom clusters](/wiki/Atom_cluster) instead. from [microparticles](/wiki/Microparticle) between 100 and 2500 and "coarse particles" (ranging from 2500 to 10,000 nm), because their smaller size drives very different physical or chemical properties, like colloidal properties and ultrafast optical effects [[4]](#cite_note-4) or electric properties. Being more subject to the [Brownian motion](/wiki/Brownian_motion), they usually do not sediment, like [colloidal particles](/wiki/Colloid) that conversely are usually understood to range from 1 to 1000 nm. Being much smaller than the wavelengths of [visible light](/wiki/Visible_light) (400-700 nm), nanoparticles cannot be seen the use of [electron microscopes or microscopes with laser](/wiki/Electron_microscope). For the same reason, dispersions of nanoparticles in transparent media can be transparent, [[5]](#cite_note-chae2003-5) whereas suspensions of larger particles usually [scatter](/wiki/Scattering) some or all visible light incident on them. Nanoparticles also easily pass through common [filters](/wiki/Filtration), such as common [ceramic candles](/wiki/Chamberland_filter), [[6]](#cite_note-simo2011-6) so that separation from liquids requires special [nanofiltration](/wiki/Nanofiltration) techniques. The properties of nanoparticles often differ markedly from those of larger particles of the same substance. Since the typical [diameter of an atom](/wiki/Atomic_radius) is between 0.15 and 0.6 nm, a large fraction of the nanoparticle's material lies within a few atomic diameters of its surface. Therefore, the properties of that surface layer may dominate over those of the bulk material. This effect is particularly strong for nanoparticles dispersed in a medium of different composition since the interactions between the two materials at their interface also becomes significant. [[7]](#cite_note-bati2015-7) Nanoparticles occur widely in nature and are objects of study in many sciences such as [chemistry](/wiki/Chemistry), [physics](/wiki/Physics), [geology](/wiki/Geology), and [biology](/wiki/Biology). Being at the transition between bulk materials and [atomic](/wiki/Atom) or [molecular](/wiki/Molecular) structures, they often exhibit phenomena that are not observed at either scale. They are an important component of [atmospheric pollution](/wiki/Atmospheric_pollution), and key ingredients in many industrialized products such as [paints](/wiki/Paint), [plastics](/wiki/Plastic), [metals](/wiki/Metal), [ceramics](/wiki/Ceramic), and [magnetic](/wiki/Magnetism) products. The production of nanoparticles with specific properties is a branch of [nanotechnology](/wiki/Nanotechnology). In general, the small size of nanoparticles leads to a lower concentration of [point defects](/wiki/Point_defect) compared to their bulk counterparts, [[8]](#cite_note-8) but they do support a variety of [dislocations](/wiki/Dislocation) that can be visualized using high-resolution [electron microscopes](/wiki/Electron_microscope). [[9]](#cite_note-9) However, nanoparticles exhibit different dislocation mechanics, which, together with their unique surface structures, results in mechanical properties that are different from the bulk material. [[10]](#cite_note-10) [[11]](#cite_note-11) [[12]](#cite_note-12) Non-spherical nanoparticles (e.g., prisms, cubes, rods etc.) and [platinum](/wiki/Platinum) (Pt) due to their fascinating optical properties are finding diverse applications. Non-spherical geometries of nanoprisms give rise to high effective cross-sections and deeper colors of the colloidal solutions. [[15]](#cite_note-ADARS108952-15) The possibility of shifting the [resonance](/wiki/Resonance) wavelengths by tuning the particle geometry allows using them in the fields of molecular labeling, biomolecular assays, trace metal detection, or nanotechnical applications. Anisotropic nanoparticles display a specific absorption behavior and stochastic particle orientation under unpolarized light, showing a distinct resonance mode for each excitable axis. [[15]](#cite_note-ADARS108952-15) Definitions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=1)] IUPAC[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=2)] In related [polymers](/wiki/Polymer), the [IUPAC](/wiki/International_Union_of_Pure_and_Applied_Chemistry) defined a nanoparticle as "a particle of any shape with dimensions in the 1 × 109 and 1 × 107 m range". [[2]](#cite_note-iupac2012a-2) This definition evolved from one given by IUPAC in 1997. [[16]](#cite_note-iupac1997-16) [[17]](#cite_note-alem2007-17) In another 2012 publication, the IUPAC extends the term to include tubes and fibers with only two dimensions below 100 nm. [[3]](#cite_note-iupac2012b-3) ISO[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=3)] According to the [International Standards Organization](/wiki/International_Standards_Organization) (ISO) technical specification [80004](/wiki/ISO/TS_80004), a nanoparticle is an object with all three external dimensions in the nanoscale, whose longest and shortest axes do not differ significantly, with a significant difference typically being a factor of at least 3. [[18]](#cite_note-iso80004-2-18) Common usage[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=4)] "Nanoscale" is usually understood to be the range from 1 to 100 nm because the novel properties that differentiate particles from the bulk material typically develop at that range of sizes. For some properties, like [transparency](/wiki/Transparency_and_translucency) or [turbidity](/wiki/Turbidity), [ultrafiltration](/wiki/Ultrafiltration), stable dispersion, etc., substantial changes characteristic of nanoparticles are observed for particles as large as 500 nm. Therefore, the term is sometimes extended to that size range.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Related concepts[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=5)] Nanoclusters are agglomerates of nanoparticles with at least one dimension between 1 and 10 nanometers and a narrow size distribution. [Nanopowders](/wiki/Nanopowder) [[19]](#cite_note-fahlm2007-19) to as [nanocrystals](/wiki/Nanocrystal). The terms [colloid](/wiki/Colloid) and nanoparticle are not interchangeable. A colloid is a mixture which has particles of one phase dispersed or suspended within an other phase. The term applies only if the particles are larger than atomic dimensions but small enough to exhibit [Brownian motion](/wiki/Brownian_motion), with the critical size range (or particle diameter) typically ranging from nanometers (109 m) to micrometers (106 m). [[20]](#cite_note-pais2005-20) Colloids can contain particles too large to be nanoparticles, and nanoparticles can exist in non-colloidal form, for examples as a powder or in a solid matrix. History[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=6)] Natural occurrence[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=7)] Nanoparticles [[21]](#cite_note-sima2018-21) geological, [[21]](#cite_note-sima2018-21) [[22]](#cite_note-sima2015-22) [meteorological](/wiki/Meteorology), and biological processes. A significant fraction (by number, if not by mass) of [interplanetary dust](/wiki/Interplanetary_dust), that is still falling on the [Earth](/wiki/Earth) at the rate of thousands of tons per year, is in the nanoparticle range; [[23]](#cite_note-plan2012-23) [[24]](#cite_note-zook2001-24) and the same is true of [atmospheric dust](/wiki/Atmospheric_dust) particles. They were used by [glassmakers](/wiki/Glassmaking) and [potters](/wiki/Pottery) in [Classical Antiquity](/wiki/Classical_Antiquity), as exemplified by [Lycurgus of [dichroic](/wiki/Dichroism) glass (4th century CE) of [Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia) (9th century CE). [[25]](#cite_note-time2016-25) [[26]](#cite_note-reiss2010-26) latter is [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=9)] [Michael Faraday](/wiki/Michael_Faraday) provided the first description, in scientific terms, of the optical properties of nanometer-scale metals in his classic 1857 paper. In a subsequent paper, the author (Turner) points out that: "It is well known that when thin leaves of gold or silver are mounted upon glass and heated to a temperature that is well below a red heat (~500 °C), a remarkable change of properties takes place, whereby the continuity of the metallic film is destroyed. The result is that white light is now freely transmitted, reflection is correspondingly diminished, while the electrical resistivity is enormously increased." [[28]](#cite_note-fara1857-28) [[29]](#cite_note-beil1903-29) [[30]](#cite_note-turn1908-30) 20th century[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=10)] During the 1970s and 80s, when the first thorough fundamental studies with nanoparticles were underway in the United States (by [Granqvist](/wiki/Claes-G%C3%B6ran_Granqvist) and [Buhrman](/w/index.php?title=Robert_A._Buhrman&action=edit&redlink=1)) [[31]](#cite_note-gran1976c-31) and Japan (within an ERATO Project), [[32]](#cite_note-haya1997-32) researchers used the term ultrafine particles. However, during the 1990s, before the [National Nanotechnology Initiative](/wiki/National_Nanotechnology_Initiative) was launched in the United States, the term nanoparticle had become more common (for example, see the same senior author's paper 20 years later addressing the same issue, lognormal distribution of sizes [[33]](#cite_note-kiss1999-33)). Morphology and structure[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=11)] Nanoparticles occur in a great variety of shapes, which have been given many informal names such may be determined by the intrinsic [crystal habit](/wiki/Crystal_habit) of the material, or by the influence of the environment around their creation, such as the inhibition of [crystal growth](/wiki/Crystal_growth) on certain faces by coating additives, the shape of [emulsion](/wiki/Emulsion) droplets and [micelles](/wiki/Micelle) in the precursor preparation, or the shape of pores in a surrounding solid matrix. [[38]](#cite_note-murp2002-38) Some applications of nanoparticles may require specific shapes, as well as specific sizes or size ranges. Amorphous particles typically adopt a spherical shape (due to their microstructural [isotropy](/wiki/Isotropy)). The study of fine particles is called [micromeritics](/wiki/Micromeritics). Variations[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=12)] Semi-solid and soft nanoparticles have been produced. A prototype nanoparticle of semi-solid nature is the [liposome](/wiki/Liposome). Various types of liposome nanoparticles are currently used clinically as delivery systems for [anticancer drugs](/wiki/Anticancer_drug) and [vaccines](/wiki/Vaccine). The breakdown of [biopolymers](/wiki/Biopolymer) into their nanoscale building blocks is considered a potential route to produce nanoparticles with enhanced [biocompatibility](/wiki/Biocompatibility) and [biodegradability](/wiki/Biodegradation). The most common example is the production of [nanocellulose](/wiki/Nanocellulose) from [wood pulp](/wiki/Wood_pulp). with one half the other half [hydrophobic](/wiki/Hydrophobic) are termed [Janus particles](/wiki/Janus_particles) and are particularly effective for stabilizing [emulsions](/wiki/Emulsion). They can [self-assemble](/wiki/Self-assembly) at water/oil [interfaces](/wiki/Interface_(matter)) and N- [isopropyl](/wiki/Isopropyl) [acrylamide](/wiki/Acrylamide) hydrogel shell can be dyed with affinity baits, internally. [[41]](#cite_note-luch2008-41) These affinity baits allow the nanoparticles to isolate and remove undesirable [proteins](/wiki/Protein) while enhancing the target analytes. Impact lays the foundation for the nanoparticle synthesis. Initial nuclei play a vital role on the size and shape of the nanoparticles that will ultimately form by acting as templating nuclei for the nanoparticle itself. Long-term stability is also determined by the initial nucleation procedures. [[42]](#cite_note-42) Homogeneous nucleation occurs when nuclei form uniformly throughout the parent phase and is less common. Heterogeneous nucleation, however, forms on areas such as container surfaces, impurities, and other defects. [[43]](#cite_note-43) Crystals may form simultaneously if nucleation is fast, creating a more monodisperse product. However, slow nucleation rates can cause formation of a polydisperse population of crystals with various sizes. Controlling nucleation allows for the control of size, dispersity, and phase of nanoparticles. The process of nucleation and growth within nanoparticles can be described by mechanism-autocatalysis model. original theory formation was [Classical Nucleation Theory](/wiki/Classical_nucleation_theory) (CNT). [[45]](#cite_note-45) It was believed that the changes in particle size could be described by burst nucleation alone. In 1950, Viktor LaMer used CNT as the nucleation basis for his model of nanoparticle growth. There are three portions to the LaMer model: 1. Rapid increase in the concentration of free monomers in solution, 2. fast nucleation of the monomer characterized by explosive growth of particles, 3. Growth of particles controlled by diffusion of the monomer. [[46]](#cite_note-46) This model describes that the growth on the nucleus is spontaneous but limited by diffusion of the precursor to the nuclei surface. The LaMer model has not been able to explain the kinetics of nucleation in [Ostwald ripening](/wiki/Ostwald_ripening) is a process in which large particles grow at the expense of the smaller particles as a result of dissolution of small particles and deposition of the dissolved molecules on the surfaces of the larger particles. It occurs because smaller particles have a higher surface energy than larger particles. [[50]](#cite_note-50) This process is typically undesirable in nanoparticle synthesis as it negatively impacts the functionality of nanoparticles.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] Two-step Finke and Watzky proposed a new kinetic model for the nucleation and growth of nanoparticles. This 2-step model suggested that constant slow nucleation (occurring far from supersaturation) is followed by autocatalytic growth where dispersity of nanoparticles is largely determined. This F-W (Finke-Watzky) 2-step model provides a firmer mechanistic basis for the design of nanoparticles with a focus on size, shape, and dispersity control. [[51]](#cite_note-51) [[52]](#cite_note-52) The model was later expanded to a 3-step and two 4-step models between 2004-2008. Here, an additional step was included to account for small particle aggregation, where two smaller particles could aggregate to form a larger particle. [[53]](#cite_note-53) Next, a fourth step (another autocatalytic step) was added to account for a small particle agglomerating with a larger particle. [[54]](#cite_note-54) [[55]](#cite_note-55) [[56]](#cite_note-56) Finally in 2014, an alternative fourth step was considered that accounted for a atomistic surface growth on a large particle. [[57]](#cite_note-57) Modeling nucleation in nanoparticles[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=18)] Recent work has begun to look at modeling the early stages of nucleation as well as the rates associated with nucleation through multiscale computational modeling. This includes exploration into an improved kinetic rate equation model as well as density function studies using the phase-field crystal model. [[58]](#cite_note-58) Measuring the rate of nucleation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=19)] The classical nucleation theory explains that the nucleation rate will correspond to the driving force One method for measuring the nucleation rate is through the induction time method. This process uses the stochastic nature of nucleation and determines the rate of nucleation by analysis of the time between constant supersaturation and when crystals are first detected. [[59]](#cite_note-59) Another method includes the probability distribution model, analogous to the methods used to study supercooled liquids, where the probability of finding at least one nucleus at a given time is derived. Properties[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=20)] The properties of a material in nanoparticle form are unusually different from those of the bulk one even when divided into micrometer-size particles. [[60]](#cite_note-buze2007-60) [[61]](#cite_note-vale2016a-61) [[62]](#cite_note-vale2016e-62) Many of them arise from spatial confinement of sub-atomic particles (i.e. electrons, protons, photons) and electric fields around these particles. The large surface to volume ratio is also significant factor at this scale. [[14]](#cite_note-Sajanlal-2011-14) Controlling properties[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=21)] The initial nucleation stages of the synthesis process heavily influence the properties of a nanoparticle. Nucleation, for example, is vital to the size of the nanoparticle. A critical radius must be met in the initial stages of solid formation, or the particles will redissolve into the liquid phase. [[63]](#cite_note-63) The final shape of a nanoparticle is also controlled by nucleation. Possible final morphologies created by nucleation can include spherical, cubic, needle-like, worm-like, and more particles. [[64]](#cite_note-64) Nucleation can be controlled predominately by time and temperature as well as the supersaturation of the liquid phase and the environment of the synthesis overall. [[65]](#cite_note-65) Large surface-area-to-volume ratio[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=22)] A bulk materials (>100 nm in size) are expected to have constant physical properties (such as [thermal](/wiki/Thermal_conductivity) and [electrical conductivity](/wiki/Electrical_conductivity), [stiffness](/wiki/Stiffness), [density](/wiki/Density), and [viscosity](/wiki/Viscosity)) regardless of its size, for nanoparticle, however, this is different: the volume of the surface layer (few atomic diameters-wide) becomes a significant fraction of the particle's volume; whereas that fraction is insignificant for particles with diameter of one [micrometer](/wiki/Micrometre) or more.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] In other words, the surface area/volume ratio impacts certain properties of the nanoparticles more prominently than in bulk particles. [[14]](#cite_note-Sajanlal-2011-14) Interfacial layer[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=23)] For nanoparticles dispersed in a medium of different composition, the interfacial layer — formed by ions and molecules from the medium that are within a few atomic diameters of the surface of each particle — can mask or change its chemical and physical properties. Indeed, that layer can be considered an integral part of each nanoparticle. [[7]](#cite_note-bati2015-7) Solvent affinity[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=24)] [Suspensions](/wiki/Suspension_(chemistry)) of nanoparticles are possible since the interaction of the particle surface with the [solvent](/wiki/Solvent) is strong enough to overcome [density](/wiki/Density) differences, which otherwise usually result in a material either sinking or floating in a liquid. Coatings[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=25)] Nanoparticles often develop or receive [coatings](/wiki/Coating) of other substances, distinct from both the particle's material and of the surrounding medium. Even when only a single molecule thick, these coatings can radically change the particles' properties, such as and chemical reactivity, catalytic activity, and stability in suspension. Diffusion across the surface[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=26)] The high surface area of a material in nanoparticle form allows heat, molecules, and ions to [diffuse](/wiki/Diffuse) into or out of the particles at very large rates. The small particle diameter, on the other hand, allows the whole material to reach homogeneous equilibrium with respect to diffusion in a very short time. Thus many processes that depend on diffusion, such as [sintering](/wiki/Sintering) can take place at lower temperatures and over shorter time scales inducing [catalysis](/wiki/Catalysis). Ferromagnetic and ferroelectric effects[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=27)] The small size of nanoparticles affects their magnetic and electric properties. The [ferromagnetic materials](/wiki/Ferromagnetic_material) in the micrometer range is a good example: widely used in [magnetic recording](/wiki/Magnetic_recording) media, for the stability of their magnetization state, those particles smaller than 10 nm are unstable and can change their state (flip) as the result of thermal energy at ordinary temperatures, thus making them unsuitable for that application. [[66]](#cite_note-gubi2009-66) Mechanical properties[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=28)] The reduced [vacancy](/wiki/Vacancy_defect) concentration in [nanocrystals](/wiki/Nanocrystal) can negatively affect the motion of [dislocations](/wiki/Dislocation), since dislocation climb requires vacancy migration. In addition, there exists a very high internal pressure due to the [surface stress](/wiki/Surface_stress) present in small nanoparticles with high [radii of curvature](/wiki/Radius_of_curvature). [[67]](#cite_note-67) This causes a [lattice](/wiki/Bravais_lattice) [strain](/wiki/Strain_(mechanics)) that is inversely proportional to the size of the particle, [[68]](#cite_note-68) also well known to impede dislocation motion, in the same way as it does in the [work hardening](/wiki/Work_hardening) of materials. [[69]](#cite_note-69) For example, [gold nanoparticles](/wiki/Gold_nanoparticle) are significantly [harder](/wiki/Hardness) than the bulk material. [[70]](#cite_note-70) Furthermore, the high surface-to-volume ratio in nanoparticles makes dislocations more likely to interact with the particle surface. In particular, this affects the nature of the [dislocation source](/wiki/Dislocation) and allows the dislocations to escape the particle before they can multiply, reducing the dislocation density and thus the extent of [plastic deformation](/wiki/Plastic_deformation). [[71]](#cite_note-71) [[72]](#cite_note-72) There are unique challenges associated with the measurement of mechanical properties on the nanoscale, as conventional means such as the [universal testing machine](/wiki/Universal_testing_machine) cannot be employed. As a result, new techniques such as [nanoindentation](/wiki/Nanoindentation) have been developed that complement existing [electron probe](/wiki/Scanning_probe_microscopy) methods. [[73]](#cite_note-73) measure [elastic modulus](/wiki/Elastic_modulus), and [adhesion](/wiki/Adhesion) between nanoparticle and substrate. [[74]](#cite_note-Guo-2014-74) The particle deformation can be measured by the deflection of the cantilever tip over the sample. The resulting force-displacement curves can be used to calculate [elastic modulus](/wiki/Elastic_modulus). [[75]](#cite_note-Tan-2004-75) However, it is unclear whether particle size and indentation depth affect the measured elastic modulus of nanoparticles by AFM. [[75]](#cite_note-Tan-2004-75) Adhesion and [friction](/wiki/Friction) important considerations in nanofabrication, lubrication, device design, colloidal stabilization, and drug delivery. [[74]](#cite_note-Guo-2014-74) The [capillary force](/wiki/Capillary_action) is the main contributor to the adhesive force under ambient conditions. [[76]](#cite_note-76) The adhesion and friction force can be obtained from the cantilever deflection if the AFM tip is regarded as a nanoparticle. However, this method is limited by tip material and geometric shape. [[77]](#cite_note-77) The [colloidal probe technique](/wiki/Colloidal_probe_technique) overcomes these issues by attaching a nanoparticle to the AFM tip, allowing control oversize, shape, and material. [[78]](#cite_note-Kappl-2002-78) While the colloidal probe technique is an effective method for measuring adhesion force, it remains difficult to attach a single nanoparticle smaller than 1 micron onto the AFM force sensor. [[78]](#cite_note-Kappl-2002-78) Another technique is in situ [TEM](/wiki/Transmission_electron_microscopy), which provides real-time, high resolution imaging of nanostructure response to a stimulus. For example, an in situ force probe holder in TEM was used to compress [twinned](/wiki/Crystal_twinning) nanoparticles and characterize [yield strength](/wiki/Yield_(engineering)). [[79]](#cite_note-79) In general, the measurement of the mechanical properties of nanoparticles is influenced by many factors including uniform dispersion of nanoparticles, precise application of load, minimum particle deformation, calibration, and calculation model. [[74]](#cite_note-Guo-2014-74) Like bulk materials, the properties of nanoparticles are materials dependent. For spherical polymer nanoparticles, [glass transition](/wiki/Glass_transition) temperature and crystallinity may affect deformation and change the elastic modulus when compared to the bulk material. [[74]](#cite_note-Guo-2014-74) However, size-dependent behavior of elastic moduli could not be generalized across polymers. [[74]](#cite_note-Guo-2014-74) As for crystalline metal nanoparticles, [dislocations](/wiki/Dislocation) were found to influence the mechanical properties of nanoparticles, contradicting the conventional view that dislocations are absent in crystalline nanoparticles. [[74]](#cite_note-Guo-2014-74) Melting point depression[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=29)] A material may have lower melting point in nanoparticle form than in the bulk form. For example, 2.5 nm gold nanoparticles melt at about 300 °C, whereas bulk gold melts 1064 °C. [[80]](#cite_note-buff1976-80) Quantum effects[ confinement](/wiki/Quantum_confinement) in [semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor) particles, surface [[81]](#cite_note-hewa2013-81) [magnetic](/wiki/Magnetic) materials. [Quantum dots](/wiki/Quantum_dots) are nanoparticles of semiconducting material that are small enough (typically sub 10 nm or less) to have quantized electronic [energy levels](/wiki/Energy_level). Quantum effects are responsible for the deep-red to black color of [gold](/wiki/Gold) or [silicon](/wiki/Silicon) nanopowders and nanoparticle suspensions. [[80]](#cite_note-buff1976-80) Absorption of solar radiation is much higher in materials composed of nanoparticles than in thin films of continuous sheets of material. In both solar [PV](/wiki/Photovoltaics) and [solar thermal](/wiki/Solar_thermal_energy) applications, by controlling the size, shape, and material of the particles, it is possible to control solar absorption. [[82]](#cite_note-wu2015-82) [[83]](#cite_note-tayl2012a-83) [[84]](#cite_note-tayl2013c-84) [[85]](#cite_note-tayl2011-85) Core-shell nanoparticles can support simultaneously both electric and magnetic resonances, demonstrating entirely new properties when compared with bare metallic nanoparticles if the resonances are properly engineered. [[86]](#cite_note-vale2018a-86) [[87]](#cite_note-tayl2013b-87) [[88]](#cite_note-chau2012-88) The formation of the core-shell structure from two different metals enables an energy exchange between the core and the shell, typically found in upconverting nanoparticles and downconverting nanoparticles, and causes a shift in the emission wavelength spectrum. [[89]](#cite_note-jacky2019-89) By introducing a dielectric layer, plasmonic core (metal)-shell (dielectric) nanoparticles enhance light absorption by increasing scattering. Recently, the metal core-dielectric shell nanoparticle has demonstrated a zero backward scattering with enhanced forward scattering on a silicon substrate when surface plasmon is located in front of a solar cell. [[90]](#cite_note-yu2017-90) Regular packing[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=31)] Nanoparticles of sufficiently uniform size may spontaneously settle into regular arrangements, forming a [colloidal crystal](/wiki/Colloidal_crystal). These arrangements may exhibit original physical properties, such as observed in [photonic crystals](/wiki/Photonic_crystal). [[91]](#cite_note-white1991-91) [[92]](#cite_note-dabbs2000-92) Production[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=32)] Artificial nanoparticles can be from any solid or liquid material, including [metals](/wiki/Metal), [dielectrics](/wiki/Dielectric), and [semiconductors](/wiki/Semiconductor). They may be internally homogeneous e.g. with a core-shell structure. [[86]](#cite_note-vale2018a-86) [[87]](#cite_note-tayl2013b-87) [[88]](#cite_note-chau2012-88) There [ball mill](/wiki/Ball_mill), a planetary [ball mill](/wiki/Ball_mill), or other size-reducing mechanism until enough of them are in the nanoscale size range. The resulting powder can be [air classified](/wiki/Elutriation) to extract [starch](/wiki/Starch) may be broken down into their individual nanoscale building blocks, obtaining [anisotropic](/wiki/Anisotropy) fiber- or needle-like nanoparticles. The biopolymers are disintegrated mechanically in combination with chemical [oxidation](/wiki/Oxidation) or [enzymatic](/wiki/Enzyme) treatment to promote breakup, or [hydrolysed](/wiki/Hydrolysis) using [acid](/wiki/Acid). Pyrolysis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=35)] Another method to create nanoparticles is to turn a suitable precursor substance, such as a gas (e.g. methane) or [aerosol](/wiki/Aerosol), into solid particles by [combustion](/wiki/Combustion) or [pyrolysis](/wiki/Pyrolysis). This is a generalization of the burning of [hydrocarbons](/wiki/Hydrocarbon) or other organic vapors to generate [soot](/wiki/Soot). Traditional [pyrolysis](/wiki/Pyrolysis) often results in aggregates and agglomerates rather than single primary particles. This inconvenience can be avoided by [ultrasonic nozzle](/wiki/Ultrasonic_nozzle) spray pyrolysis, in which the precursor liquid is forced through an orifice at high pressure. Condensation from plasma[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=36)] Nanoparticles [carbides](/wiki/Carbide), and [nitrides](/wiki/Nitride), can be created by vaporizing the solid with a [thermal plasma](/wiki/Plasma_(physics)), which can reach temperatures of 10,000 [kelvin](/wiki/Kelvin), and then condensing the vapor by expansion or quenching in a suitable gas or liquid. The plasma can be produced by [dc jet](/w/index.php?title=Plasma_jet&action=edit&redlink=1), [electric arc](/wiki/Electric_arc), or [radio frequency by the [exploding wire method](/wiki/Exploding_wire_method). In RF induction plasma torches, energy coupling to the plasma is accomplished through the electromagnetic field generated by the induction coil. The plasma gas does not come in contact with electrodes, thus eliminating possible sources of contamination and allowing the operation of such plasma torches with a wide range of gases including inert, reducing, oxidizing, and other corrosive atmospheres. The working frequency is typically between 200 kHz and 40 MHz. Laboratory units run at power levels in the order of 30-50 kW, whereas the large-scale industrial units have been tested at power levels up to 1 MW. As the residence time of the injected feed droplets in the plasma is very short, it is important that the droplet sizes are small enough in order to obtain complete evaporation. Inert gas condensation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=37)] [Inert-gas](/wiki/Inert_gas) [condensation](/wiki/Condensation) is frequently used to produce metallic nanoparticles. The metal is evaporated in a vacuum chamber containing a reduced atmosphere of an inert gas. [[98]](#cite_note-gran1976-98) Condensation of the supersaturated metal vapor results in creation of nanometer-size particles, which can be entrained in the inert gas stream and deposited on a substrate or studied in situ. Early studies were based on thermal evaporation. [[98]](#cite_note-gran1976-98) Using [magnetron sputtering](/wiki/Sputter_deposition) to create the metal vapor allows to achieve higher yields. [[99]](#cite_note-hahn1990-99) The method can easily be generalized to alloy nanoparticles by choosing appropriate metallic targets. The use of sequential growth schemes, where the particles travel through a second metallic vapor, results in growth of core-shell (CS) structures. [[100]](#cite_note-wang2005-100) [[101]](#cite_note-henn2014-101) [[102]](#cite_note-llam2014-102) [gamma rays](/wiki/Gamma_ray) can create strongly active [free radicals](/wiki/Free_radicals) in solution. This relatively simple technique uses a minimum number of chemicals. These including water, a soluble metallic salt, a radical scavenger (often a secondary alcohol), and a surfactant (organic capping agent). High gamma doses on the order of 104 [gray](/wiki/Gray_(unit)) are required. In this process, reducing radicals will drop metallic ions down to the zero-valence state. A scavenger chemical will preferentially interact with oxidizing radicals to prevent the re-oxidation of the metal. Once in the zero-valence state, metal atoms begin to coalesce into particles. A chemical surfactant surrounds the particle during formation and regulates its growth. In sufficient concentrations, the surfactant molecules stay attached to the particle. This prevents it from dissociating or forming clusters with other particles. Formation of nanoparticles using the radiolysis method allows for tailoring of particle size and shape by adjusting precursor concentrations and gamma dose. [[104]](#cite_note-bello1998-104) Wet chemistry[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=39)] Nanoparticles of certain materials can be created by "wet" chemical processes, in which [solutions](/wiki/Solution_(chemistry)) of suitable compounds are mixed or otherwise treated to form an insoluble [precipitate](/wiki/Precipitate) of the desired material. The size of the particles of the latter is adjusted by choosing the concentration of the reagents and the temperature of the solutions, and through the addition of suitable inert agents that affect the viscosity and diffusion rate of the liquid. With different parameters, the same general process may yield other nanoscale structures of the same material, such as [aerogels](/wiki/Aerogel) and other porous networks. [[105]](#cite_note-brin1990-105) The nanoparticles formed by this method are then separated from the solvent and soluble byproducts of the reaction by a combination of [evaporation](/wiki/Evaporation), [sedimentation](/wiki/Sedimentation), [centrifugation](/wiki/Centrifugation), washing, and [filtration](/wiki/Filtration).Alternatively, if the particles are meant to be deposited on the surface of some solid substrate, the starting solutions can be by coated on that surface by dipping or [spin-coating](/wiki/Spin-coating), and the reaction can be carried out in place. [Electroless deposition](/wiki/Electroless_deposition) provides a unique opportunity for growing nanoparticles onto surface without the need for costly spin coating, electrodeposition, or physical vapor deposition. Electroless deposition processes can form colloid suspensions catalytic metal or metal oxide deposition. The suspension of nanoparticles that result from this process is an example of [colloid](/wiki/Colloid). Typical instances of this method are the production of metal [oxide](/wiki/Oxide) or [hydroxide](/wiki/Hydroxide) nanoparticles by [hydrolysis](/wiki/Hydrolysis) of metal [alkoxides](/wiki/Alkoxide) and [chlorides](/wiki/Chloride). [[106]](#cite_note-hench1990-106) [[5]](#cite_note-chae2003-5) Besides being cheap and convenient, the wet chemical approach allows fine control of the particle's chemical composition. Even small quantities of dopants, such as organic dyes and rare earth metals, can be introduced in the reagent solutions end up uniformly dispersed in the final product. [[107]](#cite_note-klein1994-107) [[108]](#cite_note-corr2009-108) Ion implantation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=40)] [Ion implantation](/wiki/Ion_implantation) may be used to treat the surfaces of dielectric materials such as sapphire and silica to make composites with near-surface dispersions of metal or nanoparticles.[ [citation Many properties of nanoparticles, notably stability, solubility, and chemical or biological activity, can be radically altered by [coating](/wiki/Coating) them with various substances — a process called functionalization. Functionalized [nanomaterial-based catalysts](/wiki/Nanomaterial-based_catalyst) can be used for catalysis of many known organic reactions. For example, suspensions of [graphene](/wiki/Graphene) particles can be stabilized by functionalization with [gallic acid](/wiki/Gallic_acid) groups. [[109]](#cite_note-sadr2017-109) For biological applications, the surface coating should be polar to give high aqueous solubility and prevent nanoparticle aggregation. In serum or on the cell surface, highly charged coatings promote non-specific binding, whereas [polyethylene glycol](/wiki/Polyethylene_glycol) linked to terminal hydroxyl or groups interactions. [[110]](#cite_note-prim1991-110) [[111]](#cite_note-liu2010-111) By the immobilization of thiol groups on the surface of nanoparticles or by coating them with [thiomers](/wiki/Thiomer) high (muco)adhesive and cellular uptake enhancing properties can be introduced. [[112]](#cite_note-112) Nanoparticles can be [linked to biological molecules](/wiki/Nanoparticle%E2%80%93biomolecule_conjugate) that can act as address tags, directing them to specific sites within the body [[113]](#cite_note-aker2002-113) specific organelles within the cell, [[114]](#cite_note-hosh2004-114) or causing them to follow specifically the movement of individual protein or RNA molecules in living cells. [[115]](#cite_note-suzu2007-115) Common address tags are [monoclonal antibodies](/wiki/Monoclonal_antibodies), [aptamers](/wiki/Aptamer), [streptavidin](/wiki/Streptavidin), or [peptides](/wiki/Peptide). These targeting agents should ideally be covalently linked to the nanoparticle and should be present in a controlled number per nanoparticle. Multivalent nanoparticles, bearing multiple targeting groups, can cluster receptors, which can activate cellular signaling pathways, and give stronger anchoring. Monovalent nanoparticles, bearing a single binding site, [[116]](#cite_note-sung2004-116) [[117]](#cite_note-fu2004-117) [[118]](#cite_note-howa2008-118) avoid clustering and so are preferable for tracking the behavior of individual proteins. It has been shown that catalytic activity and sintering rates of a functionalized nanoparticle catalyst is correlated to nanoparticles' number density [[119]](#cite_note-119) Coatings that mimic those of red blood cells can help nanoparticles evade the immune system. [[120]](#cite_note-physwo2011-120) Uniformity requirements[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=42)] The chemical processing and synthesis of high-performance technological components for the private, industrial, and military sectors requires the use of high-purity [ceramics](/wiki/Ceramic_materials) Cu + C). In condensed bodies formed from fine powders, the irregular particle sizes and shapes in a typical powder often lead to non-uniform packing morphologies that result in packing density variations in the powder compact. Uncontrolled [agglomeration](/wiki/Flocculation) of powders due to [attractive](/wiki/Force) [van der Waals forces](/wiki/Van_der_Waals_forces) can also give rise to microstructural heterogeneity. Differential stresses that develop as a result of non-uniform drying shrinkage are directly related to the rate at which the [solvent](/wiki/Solvent) can be removed, and thus highly dependent upon the distribution of [porosity](/wiki/Porosity). Such stresses have been associated with a plastic-to-brittle transition in consolidated bodies, and can yield to [crack propagation](/wiki/Crack_propagation) in the unfired body if not relieved. [[121]](#cite_note-onoda1979-121) [[122]](#cite_note-aksay1983-122) [[123]](#cite_note-fran1996-123) In addition, any fluctuations in packing density in the compact as it is prepared for the kiln are often amplified during the [sintering](/wiki/Sintering) process, yielding inhomogeneous densification. Some pores and other structural defects associated with density variations have been shown to play a detrimental role in the sintering process by growing and thus limiting end-point densities. Differential stresses arising from inhomogeneous densification have also been shown to result in the propagation of internal cracks, thus becoming the strength-controlling flaws. [[124]](#cite_note-evan1969b-124) [[125]](#cite_note-evan1970c-125) [[126]](#cite_note-lange1983-126) Inert gas evaporation and inert gas deposition [[31]](#cite_note-gran1976c-31) [[32]](#cite_note-haya1997-32) are free many of these defects due to the distillation (cf. purification) nature of the process and having enough time to form single crystal particles, however even their non-aggreated deposits have [lognormal](/wiki/Lognormal) size distribution, which is typical with nanoparticles. [[32]](#cite_note-haya1997-32) The reason why modern gas evaporation techniques can produce a relatively narrow size distribution is that aggregation can be avoided. [[32]](#cite_note-haya1997-32) However, even in this case, random residence times in the growth zone, due to the combination of drift and diffusion, result in a size distribution appearing lognormal. [[33]](#cite_note-kiss1999-33) It would, therefore, appear desirable to process a material in such a way that it is physically uniform with regard to the distribution of components and porosity, rather than using particle size distributions that will maximize the green density. The containment of a uniformly dispersed assembly of strongly interacting particles in suspension requires total control over interparticle forces. [Monodisperse](/wiki/Monodisperse) nanoparticles and colloids provide this potential. [[127]](#cite_note-evan1987d-127) Characterization[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=43)] Nanoparticles have different analytical requirements than conventional chemicals, for which chemical composition and concentration are sufficient metrics. Nanoparticles have other physical properties that must be measured for a complete description, such as [size](/wiki/Particle_size), [shape](/wiki/Shape), [surface properties](/wiki/Surface_science), [crystallinity](/wiki/Crystallinity), and [dispersion laboratory procedures can perturb their dispersion state or bias the distribution of other properties. [[128]](#cite_note-hass2008-128) [[129]](#cite_note-powe2007-129) In environmental contexts, an additional challenge is that many methods cannot detect low concentrations of nanoparticles that may still have an adverse effect. [[128]](#cite_note-hass2008-128) For some applications, nanoparticles may be characterized in complex matrices such as water, soil, food, polymers, inks, complex mixtures of organic liquids such as in cosmetics, or blood. [[130]](#cite_note-boxa2008-130) [[131]](#cite_note-lins2011-131) There are several overall categories of methods used to characterize nanoparticles. [Microscopy](/wiki/Microscopy) methods generate images of individual nanoparticles to characterize their shape, size, and location. [Electron microscopy](/wiki/Electron_microscopy) and [scanning probe microscopy](/wiki/Scanning_probe_microscopy) are the dominant methods. Because nanoparticles have a size below the [diffraction limit](/wiki/Diffraction-limited_system) of [visible light](/wiki/Visible_light), conventional [optical microscopy](/wiki/Optical_microscope) is not useful. Electron microscopes can be coupled to spectroscopic methods that can perform [elemental analysis](/wiki/Elemental_analysis). Microscopy methods are destructive and can be prone to undesirable [artifacts](/wiki/Artifact_(error)) from sample preparation, or from probe tip geometry in the case of scanning probe microscopy. Additionally, microscopy is based on [single-particle measurements](/wiki/Single-molecule_experiment), meaning that large numbers of individual particles must be characterized to estimate their bulk properties. [[128]](#cite_note-hass2008-128) [[130]](#cite_note-boxa2008-130) [Spectroscopy](/wiki/Spectroscopy), which measures the particles' interaction with [electromagnetic radiation](/wiki/Electromagnetic_radiation) as a function of [wavelength](/wiki/Wavelength), is useful for some classes of nanoparticles to characterize concentration, size, and shape. [X-ray](/wiki/X-ray_spectroscopy), [ultraviolet-visible](/wiki/Ultraviolet%E2%80%93visible_spectroscopy), [infrared](/wiki/Infrared_spectroscopy), and [nuclear magnetic [neutron scattering](/wiki/Neutron_scattering) are used to determine particle size, with each method suitable for different size ranges and particle compositions. [[128]](#cite_note-hass2008-128) [[130]](#cite_note-boxa2008-130) Some miscellaneous methods are [electrophoresis](/wiki/Electrophoresis) for surface charge, the [Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method](/wiki/BET_theory) for surface area, and [X-ray diffraction](/wiki/X-ray_diffraction) for crystal structure, [[128]](#cite_note-hass2008-128) as well as [mass spectrometry](/wiki/Mass_spectrometry) for particle [[130]](#cite_note-boxa2008-130) [Chromatography](/wiki/Chromatography), [centrifugation](/wiki/Centrifugation), and [filtration](/wiki/Filtration) techniques can be used to separate nanoparticles by size or other physical properties before or during characterization. [[128]](#cite_note-hass2008-128) Health and safety[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=44)] Nanoparticles present possible dangers, both medically and environmentally. [[133]](#cite_note-zoro2014-133) [[134]](#cite_note-cris2017-134) [[135]](#cite_note-mnyu2003-135) [[136]](#cite_note-mu2013-136) Most of these are due to the high surface to volume ratio, which can make the particles very reactive or [catalytic](/wiki/Catalytic). [[137]](#cite_note-ying2016-137) They are also thought to aggregate on phospholipid bilayers [[138]](#cite_note-138) and pass through [cell membranes](/wiki/Cell_membrane) in organisms, and their interactions with biological systems are relatively unknown. [[139]](#cite_note-euheXXXX-139) [[140]](#cite_note-thak2013-140) However, it is unlikely the particles would enter the cell nucleus, Golgi complex, endoplasmic reticulum or other internal cellular components due to the particle size and intercellular agglomeration. [[141]](#cite_note-greu2011-141) A recent study looking at the effects of [ZnO](/wiki/ZnO) nanoparticles on human immune cells has found varying levels of susceptibility to [cytotoxicity](/wiki/Cytotoxicity). [[142]](#cite_note-hanle2009-142) There are concerns that pharmaceutical companies, seeking regulatory approval for nano-reformulations of existing medicines, are relying on safety data produced during clinical studies of the earlier, pre-reformulation version of the medicine. This could result in regulatory bodies, such as the FDA, missing new side effects that are specific to the nano-reformulation. [[143]](#cite_note-vines2009-143) However considerable research has demonstrated that zinc nanoparticles are not absorbed into the bloodstream in vivo. [[144]](#cite_note-bens2005-144) Concern has also been raised over the health effects of respirable nanoparticles from certain combustion processes. [[145]](#cite_note-howa2009-145) [[146]](#cite_note-piet2015-146) Preclinical investigations have demonstrated that some inhaled or injected noble metal nano-architectures avoid persistence in organisms. [[147]](#cite_note-147) [[148]](#cite_note-148) As of 2013 the [U.S. Environmental Protection Agency](/wiki/U.S._Environmental_Protection_Agency) was investigating the safety of the following nanoparticles: [[149]](#cite_note-epa2013a-149) [Carbon nanotubes](/wiki/Carbon_nanotube): Carbon materials have a wide range of uses, ranging from composites for use in vehicles and sports equipment to integrated circuits for electronic components. The interactions between nanomaterials such as carbon nanotubes and natural organic matter strongly influence both their aggregation and deposition, which strongly affects their transport, transformation, and exposure in aquatic environments. In past research, carbon nanotubes exhibited some toxicological impacts that will be evaluated in various environmental settings in current EPA chemical safety research. EPA research will provide data, models, test methods, and best practices to discover the acute health effects of carbon nanotubes and identify methods to predict them. [[149]](#cite_note-epa2013a-149) [Cerium oxide](/wiki/Cerium(IV)_oxide): Nanoscale cerium oxide is used in electronics, biomedical supplies, energy, and fuel additives. Many applications of engineered cerium oxide nanoparticles naturally disperse themselves into the environment, which increases the risk of exposure. There is ongoing exposure to new diesel emissions using fuel additives containing CeO2 nanoparticles, and the environmental and public health impacts of this new technology are unknown. EPA's chemical safety research is assessing the environmental, ecological, and health implications of nanotechnology-enabled diesel fuel additives. [[149]](#cite_note-epa2013a-149) [Titanium dioxide](/wiki/Titanium_dioxide): Nano titanium dioxide is currently used in many products. Depending on the type of particle, it may be found in sunscreens, cosmetics, and paints and coatings. It is also being investigated for use in removing contaminants from drinking water. [[149]](#cite_note-epa2013a-149) [Nano Silver](/wiki/Nano_Silver): Nano Silver is being incorporated into textiles, clothing, food packaging, and other materials to eliminate bacteria. EPA and the [U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission](/wiki/U.S._Consumer_Product_Safety_Commission)are studying certain products to see whether they transfer nano-size silver particles in real-world scenarios. EPA is researching this topic to better understand how much nano-silver children come in contact with in their environments. [[149]](#cite_note-epa2013a-149) - Iron: While [nano-scale iron](/wiki/Nano-scale_iron)is being investigated for many uses, including "smart fluids" for uses such as [optics polishing](/wiki/Optics_polishing)and as a better-absorbed [iron nutrient supplement](/wiki/Iron_nutrient_supplement), one of its more prominent current uses is to remove contamination from groundwater. This use, supported by EPA research, is being piloted at a number of sites across the United States. [[149]](#cite_note-epa2013a-149) Regulation[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Nanoparticle&action=edit§ion=45)] As of 2016, the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency had conditionally registered, for a period of four years, only two nanomaterial pesticides as ingredients. The EPA differentiates nanoscale ingredients from non-nanoscale forms of the ingredient, but there is little scientific data about potential variation in toxicity. Testing protocols still need to be developed.
